Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from my mother: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Call when you can.” I glance at it, guilt pricking at me. I haven’t spoken to my parents in over a week, and I know they worry when I go silent. I promised myself I’d call them today, just to check in, to be a good son. But as I set my phone down, it rings again—this time, it’s the synagogue office. A congregant has passed away, and the family is distraught. They need me to officiate the funeral, to comfort them, to be present as their rabbi. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in: my parents’ gentle expectation for connection, and my community’s urgent need for guidance and support. My heart aches with the knowledge that, whatever I choose, I will be letting someone down. I stare at my phone, torn, the demands of being a child and a rabbi pulling me in opposite directions.
